awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Temporal Dynamics of Pacific Kelp Forest Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Many species are threatened because of climate change and human impacts. By examining how species lived before human environmental influences, we can help mitigate future environmental change. This project studies Pacific kelp forests. Today, these nearshore habitats are vulnerable because of their proximity to large cities. The fellow will use chemical techniques to quantify the importance of kelp to ancient fish and marine mammals using bones collected from archaeological sites. Sites range from Alaska to southern California, and date from 12,000 years ago to modern day. Additionally, the fellow will characterize nutrient flow between kelp forests and nearby open ocean habitats. Overall, this project provides a picture of what habitats along the Pacific coast of North America looked like prior to European contact. The work is important not just for species living in kelp forests, but for human communities relying on them. The fellow will present this research to visitors at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (NMNH), and develop learning modules for high schools and scientific researchers. 

This research will examine the dynamics of Pacific kelp forest ecosystems over the Holocene and Anthropocene. Incorporating data from archaeological contexts adds to our understanding of these ecosystems by providing a pre-industrial baseline. The fellow will conduct delta13-C analysis of essential amino acids (EAA) on faunal remains from archaeological sites to reconstruct the importance of kelp-derived energy to ancient food webs. Sites span the northeast Pacific margin and past 12,000 years. At each location, the fellow will analyze fauna from three distinct functional groupings benthic, pelagic or mixed-habitat foragers to quantify kelp versus pelagically-derived energy. The fellow will compare these to analogous modern fauna to characterize ecosystem change. The fellow will work at the Smithsonian NMNH, a premier research and educational institute and popular cultural attraction. The fellow will: 1) learn important curatorial and faunal identification skills, and 2) interact directly with the general public about the importance of kelp forest ecosystems. The fellow will also develop curriculum based around historical conservation ecology for use in high schools. This research aids in understanding kelp forests dynamics, and engages scientists and the public in their protection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Goals, Intellectual and Broader Merit:

To fully understand the processes governing ecological dynamics, we need to consider the environmental conditions experienced by animal communities in the past, and the changing role of humans within food webs. Historical studies of human-ecosystem dynamics are particularly topical for marine habitats, which are under considerable threat from global change, and suffer from a shifting baseline syndrome owing to species declines prior to the advent of modern monitoring programs. A historical perspective can fill this gap by providing local-level ecological data prior to intensive modern human impacts. Historical studies also offer unique insights by identifying specific environmental and cultural contexts where human harvesting of marine resources has persisted with minimal ecological impacts over long time scales. This project employs cutting edge analytical techniques (bulk tissue and essential amino acid stable isotope analysis) of zooarchaeological remains to characterize the structure and dynamics of coastal ecosystems prior to industrial impacts. In particular, this work focuses on Pacific kelp forests which harbor many species of commercial and cultural importance to human communities.

 

The project took place at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (NMNH), and was led by postdoctoral fellow Dr. Emma Elliott Smith, with mentorship and training from NMNH curator Dr. Torben Rick.

 

 

--------------------------------

Research outcomes:

This project produced isotopic data for over 200 specimens from coastal archaeological sites. The dataset encompasses faunal remains from sites from southern California and northern Oregon, and over 20 species/broader taxonomic groups. Analysis of these data resulted in two peer-reviewed first author papers published by the fellow, and one additional manuscript in review. As part of the fellowship activities, the fellow also published works characterizing the structure of modern kelp forest food webs and critical knowledge gaps.

 

These works made significant contributions the field of ecology and global change biology by characterizing the sources of energy supporting modern and historical coastal food webs and individual marine species. In particular, the products from this work have provided the following novel insights:

  1. Historical ecology of green and white sturgeon (Elliott Smith et al. 2022, QSA), and swordfish (Elliott Smith et al. In Review, MEPS) though genetic, zooarchaeological, and isotopic analysis of preserved bone tissue. These findings from these works demonstrate similar ecologies of all species in past and present contexts and highlight the value of isotope data to elucidate past patterns of human fishing strategies and environmental change and provide baseline data for contemporary fisheries.
  2. New perspectives into the nature of historical fisheries and the structure of coastal food webs (Elliott Smith et al. In Press, The Holocene) through zooarchaeological, bulk tissue and essential amino acid isotopic analyses of 16 fish genera/families. Isotopic data revealed that the historical fish community relied on basal resources from kelps and phytoplankton. This coupling of benthic and pelagic energy sources suggests late Holocene coastal food webs in the region (southern California) were in a relatively stable configuration immediately prior to first European arrival.
  3. Quantification of the structure of modern kelp forest food webs in South America and around the globe (Elliott Smith & Fox 2021, Ecography; Elliott Smith et al. Ecology). These works have demonstrated that kelp is important for modern consumers as both a food and habitat resource and highlighted critical gaps in our understanding of modern kelp forest ecology.

 

The project also led to significant training and professional development outcomes for the fellow (Dr. Elliott Smith). Through work with Dr. Rick at the Smithsonian NMNH Elliott Smith gained new skills (1) in identification of coastal fishes from osteological remains, (2) curation and collections management, (3) interdisciplinary studies of coupled socio-environmental systems. Elliott Smith also developed professional packets for academic and federal job application with mentorship from Dr. Rick.

 

--------------------------------

Broader Impacts:

The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a significant reduction of planned broader impact activities, including the cancelation of planned international travel and workshops. However, the fellow nonetheless engaged in numerous activities which disseminated research findings to the broader community, as well as provided training for future generations of STEM talent. These activities included:

  • Participation by the fellow in Smithsonian programs such as Science Snapshots which connect NMNH researchers with interested student interns.
  • Participation by the fellow at IsoCamp, a two-week training course at the University of New Mexico open to graduate and post-graduate researchers around the globe.
  • Participation by the fellow in a semester long training program focused on developing antiracist policies within STEM – Unlearning Racism in Geoscience (URGE).
  • Direct mentorship provided by the fellow for undergraduate and graduate students in isotopic studies of marine species and kelp forest ecosystems.
